Award.AwardTitle: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: Rapidly tunable quantum cascade lasers for FM optical links and spectroscopy

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this research is to study both theoretically and experimentally the mechanisms and limitations of rapid electrical control of the emission frequency in single-mode quantum cascade lasers using bias control of the modal effective refractive index. Rapidly tunable single-mode quantum cascade lasers with all-electrical control of the emission frequency will be used to demonstrate a prototype of a free-space optical frequency-modulation link.
Intellectual Merits
The proposed research is aimed at further exploration of the unique physics and design flexibility of quantum cascade lasers. We will study a delicate interplay between the effectiveness of voltage control of the devices frequency and their performance characteristics. This work will create knowledge needed of the realization of mid-infrared semiconductor lasers that can be frequency modulated at speeds well above 1 GHz.
Broader Impacts
The proposed research contains elements of many disciplines, including quantum mechanics, optics, high-frequency electronics, and semiconductor microfabrication and provides an excellent educational environment for graduate and undergraduate students. Knowledge developed during the research will be incorporated into graduate-level courses taught by the principle investigators, and disseminated to the research community through publications, technology transfer, and the research group websites. The devices developed over the course of this project are expected to enable the creation of high-fidelity optical communication links based on frequency-modulation in the 8-12 microns atmospheric transparency window.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A rapidly tunable single mode laser is a key element of a revolutionary new optical frequency modulation (OFM) communication system. An OFM data link is expected to have orders of magnitude signal-to-noise ratio advantage over a conventional amplitude modulation system [1]. Among the existing ways of the laser frequency tuning there is no one which could provide the high tuning speed which is required for the communication applications.

Free space communication system is not the only area where optically tunable QCLs can be used. It was recently reported that application of optically tunable QCL in a chemical sensor made possible a 10 time improvement in the noise equivalent sensitivity [2].

A new approach to rapid laser tuning has been developed in the Optoelectronics group of SUNY in collaboration with the University of Texas at Austin. In this approach the emission frequency of the signal transmitting laser is modulated by the light of another laser. In the experiment performed in the SUNY Optoelectronics Laboratory, the frequency of a high performance single mode long wavelength quantum cascade laser (QCL) was modulated by illumination of the QCL stripe by an out-of-shelf mid-IR telecom laser. The variation of the mid-IR pumping intensity resulted in the change in the QCL generation frequency. The mid-IR emission was coupled to the QCL through the substrate which is transparent to the pumping wavelength. This made possible to pump uniformly the entire QCL stripe and increase the pumping efficiency. A tuning range of 0.6 cm-1 (20GHz) and wavelength modulation frequency up to 300MHz was demonstrated at room temperature [3]. This tuning range is about 2000 times larger than a typical linewidth of a single mode QCL.

The effects of optically generated charge carriers on the QCL optical loss and effective refractive index were investigated theoretically and experimentally. The obtained information enriched our understanding of light-matter interaction processes in a semiconductor heterostructures.

  1. S. Luryi and M. Gouzman, International Journal of High Speed Electronics, v.16, 7 (2006).
  2. Yang, Tao; Tian, Chao; Chen, Gang; et al.,” Non-resonant optical modulation of quantum cascade laser and its application potential in infrared spectroscopy”, NOVEL IN-PLANE SEMICONDUCTOR LASERS XIII, Edited by: Belyanin, AA; Smowton, PM, Book Series: Proceedings of SPIE, v. 9002, 90021T (2014).
  3. Sergey Suchalkin, Gregory Belenky , Takashi Hosoda , Seungyong Jung , Mikhail A. Belkin, “Distributed Feedback Quantum Cascade Laser with optically tunable emission frequency”, Applied Physics Letters, v.103, 041120 (2013).
